questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-week history of a foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. She also had one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this period. She has been mouth breathing in her sleep for the past 4 days. She was born at term. Her 1-year-old brother was treated for viral gastroenteritis 3 weeks ago.  She is at 60th percentile for height and at 70th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg. Examination shows mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Oral and otoscopic examination is unremarkable. Endoscopic examination of the nose confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transnasal puncture and stenting are used to treat choanal atresia, a congenital condition. Bilateral choanal atresia usually manifests in infancy, whereas the unilateral form manifests later in life with chronic rhinitis of the affected nasal passage. The timeframe of this patient's symptoms makes bilateral atresia unlikely, however, and unilateral atresia does not typically manifest with foul-smelling or blood-tinged nasal drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

Tumor embolization is used to treat juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a locally invasive vascular tumor that typically manifests with episodic epistaxis and nasal obstruction. This child only had a single episode of blood-tinged fluid. Also, these tumors occur virtually exclusively in adolescent males.

C) CORRECT:

A foreign nasal body should be suspected in any young child with unilateral nasal discharge (most commonly seen in patients 1–5 years of age). The presence of unilateral symptoms can help rule out differential diagnoses, such as chronic rhinosinusitis or upper respiratory tract infection, which generally manifest bilaterally. The foreign object causes local inflammatory reactions, which can lead to foul-smelling nasal discharge, epistaxis, and may progress to secondary infection. Diagnosis is established via direct visualization of the foreign body via anterior rhinoscopy, or, if the foreign body is not visualized on anterior rhinoscopy, flexible fiberoptic nasolaryngoscopy. Removal of the foreign body is first attempted through noninvasive techniques (e.g., positive pressure techniques). If unsuccessful, instrumentation techniques (e.g., extraction with forceps) may be necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

A septoplasty can be used to correct a nasal septum deviation. Severe septum deviation can cause sinus infections, sleep apnea, and snoring. This patient does not have any symptoms that would suggest sinus infection (e.g., fever or headache). Although mouth breathing is reported, there is no history of snoring or apnea.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional endoscopic sinus surgery is used to restore sinus ventilation and function in patients with chronic sinusitis who have not responded to medical therapy. Patients with chronic sinusitis typically present with bilateral mucopurulent drainage from the nose or the nasopharynx, nasal congestion, facial pain, and/or impaired sense of smell. Because this patient's symptoms are inconsistent with chronic sinusitis, this procedure is not indicated.
Image Description:

CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane)

The ethmoid sinuses are opacified (hatched green overlay) and there is lobulated thickening of the walls of the maxillary sinuses (green overlay). The findings indicate nasal polyps and retention cysts.

F) INCORRECT:

Adenoidectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with symptomatic adenoid vegetations. While adenoid hypertrophy can manifest with mucopurulent nasal discharge and mouth breathing, the discharge is usually nonbloody and affects both nostrils. Also, the enlarged adenoids would have been visualized during oral examination.

G) INCORRECT:

Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy can be used to treat allergic/vasomotor rhinitis or nasal polyposis. Rhinitis generally manifests with bilateral symptoms. Nasal polyps are more common in adults and typically develop in patients with allergic rhinitis, cystic fibrosis, or asthma due to chronic inflammation. This patient has unilateral symptoms and does not have any risk factors for nasal polyps.
questions.hint: Note that the child has strictly unilateral nasal symptoms.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of rhinorrhea and cough, and 2 days of purulent discharge from the right nostril. She is breathing through her mouth at rest, and there is blood-tinged, foul-smelling discharge from her right nostril. Her parents report one episode of brief right-sided epistaxis, which resolved with direct pressure. She has no history of trauma. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
She lives at home with her mother and father. There is no family history of bleeding disorders, but both parents have seasonal allergies.
On examination, the patient is afebrile but uncomfortable. She continually rubs her nose and sneezes intermittently. She has prominent vasculature and discharge in her right nostril but no active bleeding. The turbinates are swollen on the right. The left nostril appears normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Evaluate for a nasal foreign body
Prescribe a twice-daily intranasal glucocorticoid, and follow up in one week
Cauterize the anterior septal blood vessels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the sinuses would not be indicated in this case until a full intranasal examination was completed. Rarely, tumors and polyps could cause similar symptoms of unilateral obstruction and bleeding, but an intranasal foreign body would need to be ruled out first.

B) CORRECT:

Nasal foreign bodies occur most often in toddlers and manifest with unilateral, foul-smelling, mucopurulent discharge, pain, and recurrent epistaxis. Typical nasal foreign bodies are food, toys, beads, and paper. Button batteries and paired disc magnets are potentially dangerous foreign bodies that can be inserted into and retained in the nose. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with a nasal foreign body.

Most nasal foreign bodies are radiolucent; however, button batteries and magnets can be seen on a plain radiograph. A plain radiograph can be considered if a foreign body is suspected but not visualized after the secretions have been suctioned out. Extraction techniques for nasal foreign bodies include positive pressure, saline washout, and mechanical extraction. Alternatively, one could consult an otolaryngologist to consider flexible nasal endoscopy.

Key learning point: Unilateral nasal discharge and epistaxis in a young child in the absence of trauma should prompt evaluation for a nasal foreign body.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanate is not warranted in this case. Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis typically causes fever and bilateral nasal discharge rather than epistaxis. Sinusitis is uncommon in infants and toddlers, as the frontal and sphenoid sinuses are not yet developed.

D) INCORRECT:

An intranasal glucocorticoid is not warranted in this case. Allergic rhinitis manifests with bilateral nasal discharge and has accompanying symptoms of sneezing, itchy eyes, and watery eyes.

E) INCORRECT:

Cauterization of Kiesselbach plexus is needed when direct pressure does not relieve bleeding. In this case, removing the nasal foreign body (if present) will stop any epistaxis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 3-week history of a foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. She also had one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this period. She has been mouth breathing in her sleep for the past 4 days. Examination shows mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Endoscopic examination of the nose confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumor embolization is used to treat juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a locally invasive vascular tumor that typically manifests with episodic epistaxis and nasal obstruction. This child only had a single episode of blood-tinged fluid. Also, these tumors occur virtually exclusively in adolescent males.

B) CORRECT:

A foreign nasal body should be suspected in any young child with unilateral nasal discharge (most commonly seen in patients 1–5 years of age). The presence of unilateral symptoms can help rule out differential diagnoses, such as chronic rhinosinusitis or upper respiratory tract infection, which generally manifest bilaterally. The foreign object causes local inflammatory reactions, which can lead to foul-smelling nasal discharge, epistaxis, and may progress to secondary infection. Diagnosis is established via direct visualization of the foreign body via anterior rhinoscopy, or, if the foreign body is not visualized on anterior rhinoscopy, flexible fiberoptic nasolaryngoscopy. Removal of the foreign body is first attempted through noninvasive techniques (e.g., positive pressure techniques). If unsuccessful, instrumentation techniques (e.g., extraction with forceps) may be necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

A septoplasty can be used to correct a nasal septum deviation. Severe septum deviation can cause sinus infections, sleep apnea, and snoring. This patient does not have any symptoms that would suggest sinus infection (e.g., fever or headache). Although mouth breathing is reported, there is no history of snoring or apnea.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenoidectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with symptomatic adenoid vegetations. While adenoid hypertrophy can manifest with mucopurulent nasal discharge and mouth breathing, the discharge is usually nonbloody and affects both nostrils. Enlarged adenoids would be visualized in an oral examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy can be used to treat allergic/vasomotor rhinitis or nasal polyposis. Rhinitis generally manifests with bilateral symptoms. Nasal polyps are more common in adults and typically develop in patients with allergic rhinitis, cystic fibrosis, or asthma due to chronic inflammation. This patient has unilateral symptoms and does not have any risk factors for nasal polyps.
questions.hint: Note that the child has strictly unilateral nasal symptoms.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her mother because of a 3-week history of foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. There was one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this time. Her mother reports that she has been mouth breathing during sleep for the past 4 days. On examination, there is mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Endoscopic examination of the nose confirms the diagnosis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumor embolization is used to treat juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a locally invasive vascular tumor that typically manifests with episodic epistaxis and nasal obstruction. This child only had a single episode of blood-tinged fluid. Also, these tumors occur virtually exclusively in adolescent males.

B) CORRECT:

A foreign nasal body should be suspected in any young child with unilateral nasal discharge (most commonly seen in patients 1–5 years of age). The presence of unilateral symptoms can help rule out differential diagnoses, such as chronic rhinosinusitis or upper respiratory tract infection, which generally manifest bilaterally. The foreign object causes local inflammatory reactions, which can lead to foul-smelling nasal discharge, epistaxis, and may progress to secondary infection. Diagnosis is established via direct visualization of the foreign body via anterior rhinoscopy, or, if the foreign body is not visualized on anterior rhinoscopy, flexible fiberoptic nasolaryngoscopy. Removal of the foreign body is first attempted through noninvasive techniques (e.g., positive pressure techniques). If unsuccessful, instrumentation techniques (e.g., extraction with forceps) may be necessary.

Key learning point: Unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge in a young child strongly suggests a nasal foreign body, which should be managed by prompt extraction to prevent complications.

C) INCORRECT:

A septoplasty can be used to correct a nasal septum deviation. Severe septum deviation can cause sinus infections, sleep apnea, and snoring. This patient does not have any symptoms that would suggest sinus infection (e.g., fever or headache). Although mouth breathing is reported, there is no history of snoring or apnea.

D) INCORRECT:

Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy can be used to treat allergic/vasomotor rhinitis or nasal polyposis. Rhinitis generally manifests with bilateral symptoms. Nasal polyps are more common in adults and typically develop in patients with allergic rhinitis, cystic fibrosis, or asthma due to chronic inflammation. This patient has unilateral symptoms and does not have any risk factors for nasal polyps.

E) INCORRECT:

Adenoidectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with symptomatic adenoid vegetations. While adenoid hypertrophy can manifest with mucopurulent nasal discharge and mouth breathing, the discharge is usually nonbloody and affects both nostrils. Enlarged adenoids would be visualized in an oral examination.
questions.hint: Note that the child has strictly unilateral nasal symptoms.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the ED with a 5-day history of with unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge. Her mother denies witnessing foreign body insertion. On anterior rhinoscopy, you visualize a metallic object lodged in the anterior nasal cavity with surrounding mucosal inflammation and swelling. The child becomes increasingly agitated during examination. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Apply topical anesthetic and attempt removal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Forceps removal should not be attempted when there is surrounding inflammation, infection, or granulation tissue, as this increases the risk for traumatic removal and tissue damage.

B) INCORRECT:

While topical anesthetic may help with patient comfort, the surrounding inflammation indicates that this patient requires an alternative step in management.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- ENT consult is indicated for nasal foreign bodies with surrounding inflammation, infection, or granulation tissue due to high risk for traumatic removal. Specialist consult is also indicated if the likelihood of successful removal is low (e.g. due to limited patient cooperation).

D) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure techniques are contraindicated when there is surrounding inflammation or infection, as they may cause further tissue damage and are less effective with impacted objects.

E) INCORRECT:

Procedural sedation alone does not address the primary issue of surrounding inflammation and granulation tissue, which requires specialist consultation for safe removal.
